elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of mellitic acid, 4,4‘-bipydine, and Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O gave rise to a novel 3D supramolecular architecture interpenetrated by three types of coordination polymer motifs. Two independent {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} 3D polymers incorporating helical substructures were interwoven into a 3D network with double-stranded helical tubes that host 1D linear polymers [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n .
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of mellitic acid, 4,4‘-bipydine, and Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O gave rise to a novel 3D supramolecular architecture interpenetrated by three types of coordination polymer motifs. Two independent {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} 3D polymers incorporating helical substructures were interwoven into a 3D network with double-stranded helical tubes that host 1D linear polymers [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n .

elements.content: Two independent {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} 3D polymers incorporating helical substructures were interwoven into a 3D network with double-stranded helical tubes that host 1D linear {[Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n polymers.
elements.clean_text: Two independent {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} 3D polymers incorporating helical substructures were interwoven into a 3D network with double-stranded helical tubes that host 1D linear {[Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n  polymers.

elements.content: Helical structures have received much attention in coordination chemistry and materials chemistry over the past decade because of the fundamental role of helicity in biology; the potential applications of such structures in the fields of supramolecular chemistry, asymmetric catalysis, and nonlinear optical material; and the aesthetically appealing structural topology. Consequently, many single-, double, and higher-order stranded helical complexes have been generated by self-assembly processes. However, the infinite double helices remain quite rare. No examples of infinite double helices with large tubes in the spiral direction have been described, although there are some reports of cavities in other directions of the helices.
elements.clean_text: Helical structures have received much attention in coordination chemistry and materials chemistry over the past decade because of the fundamental role of helicity in biology; the potential applications of such structures in the fields of supramolecular chemistry, asymmetric catalysis, and nonlinear optical material; and the aesthetically appealing structural topology. Consequently, many single-, double, and higher-order stranded helical complexes have been generated by self-assembly processes. However, the infinite double helices remain quite rare. No examples of infinite double helices with large tubes in the spiral direction have been described, although there are some reports of cavities in other directions of the helices.

elements.content: Structural interpenetration has been widely involved in supramolecular chemistry systems, and some helical structures reported in the literature have been constructed by interpenetration. Usually, interpenetration precludes the existence of frameworks with very large cavities. Yaghi and co-workers made use of the strategy for the design of a highly porous and structurally stable coordination network in which interwoven pairs of metal−organic frameworks were mutually reinforced. Several examples of coordination networks constructed by chemically or crystallographically distinct polymeric building motifs have been reported. In this communication, we present a first example of a self-assembled 3D architecture that comprises interesting double helical host tubes filled by 1D guest metal−organic polymer chains.
elements.clean_text: Structural interpenetration has been widely involved in supramolecular chemistry systems, and some helical structures reported in the literature have been constructed by interpenetration. Usually, interpenetration precludes the existence of frameworks with very large cavities. Yaghi and co-workers made use of the strategy for the design of a highly porous and structurally stable coordination network in which interwoven pairs of metal-organic frameworks were mutually reinforced. Several examples of coordination networks constructed by chemically or crystallographically distinct polymeric building motifs have been reported. In this communication, we present a first example of a self-assembled 3D architecture that comprises interesting double helical host tubes filled by 1D guest metal-organic polymer chains.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of mellitic acid, 4,4‘-bpy, and Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O produced blue crystals of a novel 3D interpenetrated supramolecular complex in high yield. X-ray crystal structural analysis revealed that the architecture consists of three polymeric motifs (Figure ):  one is the guest cation with a [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4] n 2 n + infinite 1D chain, the other two have the same component of {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} n . In total, the architecture can be formulated as {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-·[Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n . TGA data suggest that the complex is almost unchanged when heated to 153 °C (Figure S3, Supporting Information)
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of mellitic acid, 4,4‘-bpy, and Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O produced blue crystals of a novel 3D interpenetrated supramolecular complex in high yield. X-ray crystal structural analysis revealed that the architecture consists of three polymeric motifs (Figure ): one is the guest cation with a [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4] n  2  n  + infinite 1D chain, the other two have the same component of {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-} n . In total, the architecture can be formulated as {[Cu2(mellitate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)2]2-⋅[Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2+} n . TGA data suggest that the complex is almost unchanged when heated to 153 °C (Figure S3, Supporting Information)

elements.content: (a) ORTEP plot of the expanded building block of host polymers; Cu = sky blue, N = deep blue, O = red. (b) Schematic representation of constructing host polymer (deep blue line represents one helix, and red represents the other) and the 1D guest chains through the double-stranded helix, where the rectangle represents the zigzag chain. (c) View of the architecture along [001]; red represent one helical coordination polymer, deep blue represents the other, and green represents the 1D inifinite guest chain. H and H2O molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP plot of the expanded building block of host polymers; Cu = sky blue, N = deep blue, O = red. (b) Schematic representation of constructing host polymer (deep blue line represents one helix, and red represents the other) and the 1D guest chains through the double-stranded helix, where the rectangle represents the zigzag chain. (c) View of the architecture along [001]; red represent one helical coordination polymer, deep blue represents the other, and green represents the 1D inifinite guest chain. H and H2O molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The host anion network is based on the expanded building block consisting of three mellitate anions, five 4,4‘-bpy ligands, and six square-pyramidally coordinated Cu(II) ions (Figure a). The interesting feature of the host polymer is that each mellitate ligand links four Cu(II) ions into an infinite zigzag chain that is represented by a rectangle. These rectangles are stacked into layers as shown in Figure b. Each rectangle connects to the adjacent rectangle at the other plane by the bridging 4,4‘-bpy ligands to complete the infinite host 3D polymer. The other infinite host polymer is formed in the same way. These two host polymers are structurally independent, and they are interwoven into 3D architecture with double-stranded helical tubes along the spiral direction. Examination of the crystal packing shows that host building blocks construct three-dimensional networks similar to the PtS structure (Figure S1). Large tubes are arranged along the spiral direction. The most significant structural feature is that the tubes are filled with guest infinite 1D linear [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2 n + polymer chains just like cables (Figure b and c and Figure b). Each tube is composed of two 2(1) helices with right-handedness (Figure a). The period of the helix is 22.3 Å by the centroid of Cu(II) ions; the distance within the double helix is about 11.16 Å along the spiral direction, and the dimension of the helical tube is approximately 8 Å × 7 Å. Cu(II) in the 1D guest polymer is six-coordinated in slightly distorted octahedral coordination, with the equatorial plane consisting of two oxygen atoms from H2O molecules and two nitrogen atoms from 4,4‘-bpy ligands, with the other two oxygen atoms from the H2O molecules occupying the axial sites.
elements.clean_text: The host anion network is based on the expanded building block consisting of three mellitate anions, five 4,4‘-bpy ligands, and six square-pyramidally coordinated Cu(II) ions (Figure a). The interesting feature of the host polymer is that each mellitate ligand links four Cu(II) ions into an infinite zigzag chain that is represented by a rectangle. These rectangles are stacked into layers as shown in Figure b. Each rectangle connects to the adjacent rectangle at the other plane by the bridging 4,4‘-bpy ligands to complete the infinite host 3D polymer. The other infinite host polymer is formed in the same way. These two host polymers are structurally independent, and they are interwoven into 3D architecture with double-stranded helical tubes along the spiral direction. Examination of the crystal packing shows that host building blocks construct three-dimensional networks similar to the PtS structure (Figure S1). Large tubes are arranged along the spiral direction. The most significant structural feature is that the tubes are filled with guest infinite 1D linear [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2  n  + polymer chains just like cables (Figure b and c and Figure b). Each tube is composed of two 2(1) helices with right-handedness (Figure a). The period of the helix is 22.3 Å by the centroid of Cu(II) ions; the distance within the double helix is about 11.16 Å along the spiral direction, and the dimension of the helical tube is approximately 8 Å × 7 Å. Cu(II) in the 1D guest polymer is six-coordinated in slightly distorted octahedral coordination, with the equatorial plane consisting of two oxygen atoms from H2O molecules and two nitrogen atoms from 4,4‘-bpy ligands, with the other two oxygen atoms from the H2O molecules occupying the axial sites.

elements.content: (a) Description of the helical tube in detail; red and deep blue represent the two strands of the double-stranded helix; Cu = blue; some C and O atoms of the mellitate and water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Representation of the space-filling 3D anion framework with 1D open tubes and the cationic chains through the tubes viewed along [010].
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Description of the helical tube in detail; red and deep blue represent the two strands of the double-stranded helix; Cu = blue; some C and O atoms of the mellitate and water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Representation of the space-filling 3D anion framework with 1D open tubes and the cationic chains through the tubes viewed along [010].

elements.content: It should be noted that there are π−π and C−H···π interactions between the three 4,4‘-bpy moieties from the guest and host polymers and that the 4,4‘-bpy ligands of the framework interact with each other in an offset fashion, with face-to-face and centriod-to-centriod distances of ca. 3.43 and 3.93 Å, respectively. Thus, π−π and C−H···π interactions, as well as the electrostatic attraction between the guest polymers and the double helices, are undoubtedly responsible for the cohesion of the whole architecture. These interactions imply host−guest molecular recognition, and the chain polymer [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2 n + plays an important role to the formation of the 3D double helical interwoven architecture.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that there are π-π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the three 4,4‘-bpy moieties from the guest and host polymers and that the 4,4‘-bpy ligands of the framework interact with each other in an offset fashion, with face-to-face and centriod-to-centriod distances of ca. 3.43 and 3.93 Å, respectively. Thus, π-π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions, as well as the electrostatic attraction between the guest polymers and the double helices, are undoubtedly responsible for the cohesion of the whole architecture. These interactions  imply host-guest molecular recognition, and the chain polymer [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)4]2  n  + plays an important role to the formation of the 3D double helical interwoven architecture.

elements.content: In summary, we present an unprecedented architecture:  a PtS-like interpenetrating network with large helical tubes that are suitable for the incorporation of 1D guest metal−organic polymers. The results show that the interpenetrating network can include other infinite linear polymers. They also show that the guest polymers play an important role in the formation of double-stranded helical tubes through specific host−guest interactions. We are presently exploring a method of replacing the guests by other polymers.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we present an unprecedented architecture: a PtS-like interpenetrating network with large helical tubes that are suitable for the incorporation of 1D guest metal-organic polymers. The results show that the interpenetrating network can include other infinite linear polymers. They also show that the guest polymers play an important role in the formation of double-stranded helical tubes through specific host-guest interactions. We are presently exploring a method of replacing the guests by other polymers.

metadata.title:
Interweaving 3D Network with Double Helical Tubes Filled by 1D
Coordination Polymer Chains
